div.head: Concerning Arthur Brooke
div.p: Little is known of the life of Arthur Brooke, or Brooke, except that he wrote Romeus and Juliet (1562) and the next year published a book entitled Agreement of Sundry Places of Scripture, ... He died that same year (1563), and an Epitaph by George Turbervile informs us that he was "drowned in passing to Newhaven."

So far as I am aware, no editor or commentator has referred to the singular prose introduction to the 1562 edition of Romeus and Juliet. ... It is signed "Ar. Br."â€”the form in which his name also appears on the title-page.

div.head: Comments on Some of the Characters
Juliet
div.p: Juliet is not fortunate in her parents. ... Her father is sixty or more years old, while her mother is about twenty-eight. ...

Earlier in the play, Capulet says to Paris: ...
"But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart, My will to her consent is but a part; An she agree, within her scope of choice, Lies my consent and fair according voice;"

div.head: Romeo
div.p: Some critics have expressed surprise that Shakespeare should have preluded the main story of the drama with the "superfluous complication" of Romeo's love for Rosaline.
